nodes.text: Major infrastructure projects systematically underestimate costs and overestimate benefits, producing cost overruns, benefit shortfalls, and a 'survival of the un-fittest' in which the projects that look best on paper are often the worst in reality

Major infrastructure projects share characteristics that increase risk: long planning horizons, complex interfaces, non-standard technology, multi-actor decision making, early lock-in of concepts, scope changes, and inadequate contingencies

Empirical evidence on cost overruns (Table 1): sample of 258 transport projects shows average cost overrun 44.7% for rail, 33.8% for bridges/tunnels, 20.4% for roads; 9 out of 10 projects have cost overrun and large standard deviations

Empirical evidence on demand forecast inaccuracy (Table 2): sample of 208 transport projects shows rail passenger traffic on average 51.4% lower than forecast, road traffic on average 9.5% higher, with large variation; rail forecasts are strongly biased upward
Cost overruns and benefit shortfalls are persistent across nations, continents, and decades and cause waste, delays, destabilized management, and increased problems as projects scale up
Three explanatory families for forecasting inaccuracy: technical errors (methods/data), psychological optimism/planning fallacy, and political-economic strategic misrepresentation
Data reject pure technical explanations: systematic biased errors (means statistically different from zero) and no improvement in accuracy over time despite methodological progress

Psychological optimism bias explains some overestimation/underestimation but is insufficient as sole cause because professional forecasters have not learned over decades and often do not report optimism as main cause
Political-economic strategic misrepresentation, driven by agency problems and incentives to secure funding, explains systematic underestimation of costs and overestimation of benefits
Interview and case-study evidence (UK and US studies) documents promoters, planners, and consultants emphasizing benefits and downplaying costs to pass approval tests and obtain scarce funds

Survival of the un-fittest mechanism: projects that are made to look best on paper (via underestimated costs and overstated benefits) are more likely to be approved but experience the largest real-world overruns and shortfalls

Reference class forecasting (the outside view) is a method to reduce bias: identify a comparable reference class, establish its outcome distribution, and position the current project in that distribution to adjust forecasts

Applications of reference class forecasting (Edinburgh Tram, Crossrail and others) produced adjusted, more conservative cost estimates and contingencies and have been formally adopted or recommended by planning bodies

Governance reforms are required to change incentives: transparency, independent peer review and benchmarking, public scrutiny, withholding categorical grants, market tests with private finance sharing risk, contract-writing capacity, and penalties for deceptive forecasting

Conclusion: Combining outside-view methods (reference class forecasting) with improved governance and accountability is necessary to mitigate systematic forecast bias and reduce wasteful, risky infrastructure projects

Current trends—large stimulus spending, rapid geographic shift of projects to emerging economies, and increasing integration of ICT into infrastructures—amplify risks of cost overruns and benefit shortfalls and raise systemic financial and economic danger
